newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE white sugar resumes bearish trend, Dec focus.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE white sugar resumes bearish trend, Dec focus.

text.p: London's spot December white sugar contract took centre stage in solid Friday volume with mixed sellers continuing to pressure nearby values after a lacklustre raws performance failed to inspire an upturn in sentiment.
After a firmer open, commission house buying interest in March and May kept both positions supported and gave the market the prospect of a corrective bounce after the recent sell off.
But with New York's March contract failing to move more than one point higher than its open, the reversal of sentiment went unconfirmed and London prices saw resumed selling pressure.
Trade and commission house players kept the two nearby contracts weighed down, although light buying kept values off the session lows.
The December/March spread was reported to be active, narrowing to $2.00 at one point. "The Dec is coming under a little bit of pressure," said one trader.
"The market's trend is down and it's in a bit of an oversold situation in both London and New York," he said.
On Thursday, the December contract ploughed through major chart support at $310 as mixed outright selling gathered pace with the decline in fortunes of the March raws.
Technical analysts have said both nearby positions are oversold and could expect an upward correction at some stage.
At 1641 GMT December was $1.10 lower at $308.00, 50 cents off its intraday low, and March was 50 cents down at $305.00.
Although the market's main open interest has shifted to the second-month March contract, December accounted for the bulk of the overall volume of 2,254 lots.
The Matif white sugar market was closed on Friday due to All Saints Day.
Traders said the market needed to see a stronger move in either direction to encourage decisive action from buyers or sellers, adding that physical offtake was also lacking.
"We're a little bit stuck -- we're seeing a little physical offtake but not enough of it. The offtake will probably come on a bounce," the trader said.

In fundamental news, Iran bought three cargoes of Thai and European Union (EU) origin white sugar for shipment in February. It bought one Thai cargo at $322 per tonne, fob, and two EU cargoes at $318 and $317.
Physical brokers said the purchases were made at relatively low prices and formed part of Iran's regular buying programme at this time of year.
